Run Code in Atom
Run selections of code or the whole file!
Currently supports:
* Bash * CoffeeScript * Erlang * Elixir * Go * Groovy * F# * Haskell * JavaScript * Julia * newLISP * Perl * PHP * Python * Ruby * Scala
You only have to add a few lines in a PR to support another.
Limitations:
* Go and F# only support file based runs
† Erlang uses erl for limited selection based runs (see #70 / https://github.com/rgbkrk/atom-script/pull/70)
\---
Source: https://atom.io/packages/script
Image / GitHub / Download: https://github.com/rgbkrk/atom-script
License: Apache License, Version 2.0 http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 https://github.com/rgbkrk/atom-script/blob/master/LICENSE.md
\---

A round of applause, please!
Please help me acknowledge +Marilyn Gerber for sharing what is the funniest hashtag I've ever seen!
If you'd like to see what all the fuss was about, go check it out for yourself: https://plus.google.com/u/0/102618047349606277909/posts/WHP1WwZibNw
In light of her witty contribution, I think I just may have to rethink my #HashTagsAreLame campaign.... ;-)﻿
Meer weergevenMinder weergeven

Take a bunch of equal-sized balls in 8 dimensions. Get as many of them to touch the same one as you possibly can. You'll get 240 balls all touching the same ball. The centers of these balls form an amazing shape in 8 dimensions! Here's an attempt to draw it in 3 dimensions.
On long bus trips in western China, I entertained myself by studying the geometry of this shape. It has:
240 vertices 6,720 edges 60,480 triangular faces 241,920 tetrahedral faces 483,840 4-dimensional faces 483,840 5-dimensional faces 207,360 6-dimensional faces 19,440 7-dimensional faces
and
696,729,600 symmetries, including rotations and reflections!
Calculating these numbers without using a computer is a fun challenge for insane people like me. I came pretty close to succeeding, and I explain how here:
http://tinyurl.com/E8-polytope
But I'm still having some problems, so if you're good at this kind of stuff, please help me out!
The cool part is that the 7-dimensional faces of this shape come in two kinds: simplexes and orthoplexes. A simplex is a higher-dimensional generalization of a triangle or tetrahedron. An orthoplex is a higher-dimensional generalization of a diamond or octahedron. I believe that you can take the orthoplexes and color their faces alternately black and white, in such a way that their black faces touch other orthoplexes, while their white faces touch simplexes. I haven't proved this, but it would explain lots of stuff.
It's sort of strange spending time on this stuff, especially because what I'm discovering must be already known. But it's curiously soothing - and it's fascinating how mental tasks that seem impossible at first turn out, with enough work, to be quite doable.
#geometry #bigness ﻿
